loans.name: Amtul's Group

texts.en:
Amtul is the resident of Faisalabad which is a big city of Pakistan and famous for its textile industry. She lives there in a 2 room brick house with her family in the area of Bhaiwala where she moved 7 years ago. She is 29 years old, married to M. Y. and has 2 children. A, four year old daughter and 2 year old son. Both have not started getting education yet. Amtul wants to enroll her daughter to school next year.

She is a caring lady, carrying out her responsibilities as a housewife and also operating her shawl (item of clothing, loosely worn over the shoulders) selling business out of her home, to supplement the income of her family. Her husband is a painter by profession. He paints on walls, houses and buildings. His business is on the basis of daily wages, so if he doesn’t get work, he doesn’t have an income. That was the reason Amtul started shawl selling business. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah. With the loan she will buy shawls of different variety, such as embroidered and simple, in bulk quantity that will help her sell more and earn a better income. She is hopeful that this investment will double her income. Amtul is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved herself to be a responsible client who never missed a single meeting and paid her installments on time. Note: In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Amtul.

loans.use: To buy shawls (item of clothing, loosely worn over the shoulders) for shawls selling business

loans.name: Davaasuren

texts.en: Davaasuren D. is 35 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Mongolia's Uvurhangai province. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional nomadic tent. His older daughter, who is six years old, attends a local primary school and his younger daughter is in kindergarten. Davaasuren makes a living selling spare parts for machines. He has been in this business for more than six years and has gained significant experience as well as built a stable company. He supplements his income by selling coal and firewood. He is applying for a loan for 2,000,000 MNT to buy more spare parts to sell.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell to his customers

loans.name: Sharol's Group

texts.en:
Sharol D. C. lives in the village of Manaoag, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 35 years old and leads a seven-person loan group. While each member receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of fellow members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Sharol is married, has three school-aged children and makes a living by making and selling food, largely at the campus of a nearby school. She has been in this line of work for more than three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Sharol joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid six previous loans from ASKI and is applying for a new one, for 12,000 PHP, to buy additional supplies and items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by her business to supplement her family's income. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional supplies and items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is treasurer of a group of small businesspeople called the Rise Group, which is funded by Juhudi Kilimo. She is a farmer from the town of Nyamira in western Kenya, where she has worked as a farmer for the last seven years. She grows maize, beans, vegetables, tea and milk, all of which she sells locally. She depends on the income from her farm to meet the needs of her family.

She has applied for a loan for 45,000 KES through Juhudi to buy and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help her pay school fees for her children and improve her family's living standards. Her main challenges have been lack of ready markets for her products, and various pests and diseases which limit her production. In the future, she would like to expand her farm and increase the number of her cows she owns   to at least four.

Jackline is married and blessed with four children. Two of her children are currently in school.

loans.use: To buy and insure a cow.

loans.name: Erdenechimeg

texts.en: Erdenechimeg D. is 41 years old and lives with her husband and three sons in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. She and her family live in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest son is university student, and her two younger sons attend high school. Her husband operates a taxi service using his own car. Erdenechimeg makes a living selling clothing and shoes which are imported from Israel in one of the main markets in the city. She also sells farming equipment in a different stall in this same market. She is doing well because she has a wide selection of items and works hard to meet her customer's needs. Her goal is to pay for her children's education and make sure they have the best possible schooling. She is applying for a loan for 1,500,000 MNT to buy winter products to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy winter products to sell to her customers

loans.name: Samdan

texts.en: Mr.D. is 42 years old, divorced and lives in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia, with his younger sister's family. In 2002, he moved to the capital from Zavkhan province, which is located far to the west, to search for better life. That same year, he also bought a minivan and started running a transportation business. He works in the suburbs, where bus service is infrequent. He supports his two children by sending money to them every month. The transportation licensing authority imposes strict health and safety requirements on vehicles that carry people. Mr. D. services and repairs his minivan very regularly, and is applying for a loan to buy the spare parts he needs to service his vehicle.

loans.use: to buy spare parts to service his minivan

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria M. is from the village of Cabaruan. She is 50 years old and married with six school-aged children. To make a living, Victoria owns a business raising and fattening pigs sale. She has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when she sells one of the raised animals.

In 2009, Victoria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI and is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Victoria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell

loans.name: Philip Kipkorir

texts.en: Philip K. is 48 years old and is from the Chebara area in Kilgoris. He is married to Rosaline Kipkorir and they have eight children aged between 15  and two. Philip has a retail shop that he has been running for the past 30 years in Chebara centre near Chebara Primary School. He is applying for his second loan from KADET LTD, after paying back the previous loan successfully. His monthly income from the business is Kshs 12,000. He will use the money to buy flour, cooking oil, tissues, bar soaps, and soft drinks to add to his stock. The family depends on him and he will use the profit to take care of the family's basic needs. His desire is to see his business expand and be able to open up a wholesale business in the future.

loans.use: To buy flour, cooking oil, tissues, bar soaps and soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Saret

texts.en:
Mrs. Saret R., 28 years old, and her husband, Mr. Sokhoeun Keo, 27 years old, live in a small village on the Mekong River about seventeen kilometers across from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 2000 and have two young daughters.  Saret has been running a grocery store in front of her house since she married. Her husband is a rice farmer. 

Saret is requesting her first a loan of $1,000 to purchase more grocery items to sell, and to put an addition on her house.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items to sell, and put an addition on her house.

loans.name: Gemma's Group

texts.en:
Gemma C. is from the village of District 1, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 43 years old and the leader of a three-member loan group offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. 

Gemma is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns a business raising and selling tilapia (St. Peter's fish) to the market. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month. 

In 2007, Gemma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI and is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase fish to sell. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Gemma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en:
Mr. Sokhom B., 55, and his wife, Mrs. Sarorn Phin, 50, (shown here) live in a small village along National Road Number three about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1983 and have three children — two sons and one daughter. Both sons are construction workers and the daughter is a garment factory worker. 

Sokhom is a taxi driver and his wife stays at home. He is in the process of building a fence around of his house, but it is not completed so he is asking for his first loan of $700 to finish it.

loans.use: To build a fence around his house.

loans.name: Phinary

texts.en:
Mrs. Phinary H. (who is in the photo) is 40 years old and her husband, Mr. Bunlong Chuk is 46 years old, have been married since 1991 and have four children. The family live on an island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Phinary is a weaver. Her husband sells silk and cotton products. He buys from other weavers in the village and from his wife’s weaving and transports them for sale in other provinces far away from his house. 

Phinary is requesting her first loan of US $600 to purchase a motorcycle for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport silk and cotton products for sale.

loans.name: Erjan

texts.en:
Erjan D. is 34 years old and lives with his wife and four sons in Bayan-Ulgiy province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest son attends a local secondary school.

Erjan operates a meat-selling business in his province. He explains that herders drive herds anywhere from 100-200 km to sell their livestock in the capital city of the province. In Mongolia, it is common for a household to buy at least one cow and ten sheep to be eaten during the long Mongolian winters. People of this province usually prepare their meats for winter in October and November and finish those prepared meats in March. As a result, Erjan plans to sell his products during the spring season. He usually purchases livestock from herders and slaughters the livestock to sell at the local market. His wife is responsible for selling the meats at the market. He sells lamb for 2,000-2,500 MNT per kilogram and horse meat for 3,000-3,500 MNT per kilogram. His net profits per day are between 10,000 and 15,000 MNT.

Erjan hopes to continue his success. He says, "All I want is to have a big house for my family." Now, he is requesting a loan in the amount of 700,000 MNT ($550) to purchase more livestock, such as 50,000-60,000 MNT per sheep and 200,000 MNT per cow, for re-sale purposes.

loans.use: To continue to expand his business by purchasing additional livestock

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica S. is a 48-year-old woman from the village of Villa Gamiao San Mateo in the Philippines. Veronica is married and has 3 adult-age children. To earn a living, Veronica owns and operates a business venture in the food sector. Her primary source of income is derived from cooking and then selling her food. At the same time, she manages a hog-raising business. Veronica has been engaged in her businesses for over 5 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2008, Veronica joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. As a result, she was better able to engage in business activities and to thereby improve her family's standard of living. Veronica is now requesting a loan in the amount of 13,000 PHP ($300), which she would like to use to purchase raw ingredients needed to make her food. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business on account of the loan to improve and expand her business. Notably, this loan would be the fifth loan taken out by Veronica from ASKI. Recently, Veronica successfully repaid a loan in the amount of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. That loan was also used to purchase raw ingredients.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen/women, and entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional raw ingredients

loans.name: Harligashim

texts.en: Harligashim S. is 34 years old and lives with her husband and 7-year-old daughter in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent home, in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of western Mongolia. Her daughter attends a local elementary school. Harligashim is a teacher with a monthly salary of 160,000 MNT and teaches lessons to handicapped and disabled people. Her husband has been working as an assistant truck driver since 2004. Depending on sales of coal, her husband earns between 100,000 and 150,000 MNT in one month. Her husband does not have his own truck, and it is difficult to work under someone. Their family's standard of living has not been improving so far. Harligashim is a hardworking and open-minded person and says, “We want to save more money in order to buy a new truck in the future.” She is requesting a loan of 1,300,000 MNT to purchase meat and coal in preparation for winter.

loans.use: To purchase meat and coal

loans.name: Roger's Group

texts.en:
Roger A. is from the village of Casalatan, Cauayan City, Isabela. He is 38 years old. Roger is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Roger is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Roger owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Roger has been engaged in his business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP monthly for these activities.

In 2008, Roger joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Roger has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Roger is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Roger from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 29-year-old married man living with his wife. He is from Lebanon. He has a lot of experience working with car spare parts. He has owned his own business since 2005. He also sells car oil from his shop. He purchases the car parts from a local commercial center to carry out his work.  Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to replenish his business tools and purchase additional tools needed. He is working toward opening a bigger store to trade and sell spare parts. He told us that he would like to one day open a commercial center and operate his own business from A to Z. He is very optimistic about his business growth in the coming years.

loans.use: To replenish his business tools and purchase additional tools needed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and preserve a large amount of dairy products.

loans.name: Isaac Mwamto

texts.en:
Isaac Mwamto O. is a 31 year old business man who is a welder who sells products made to his customers at a profit. He is married to Susan Imbosa and together they have four children ages 9, 7, 6, and 2 years old. He runs his business in Lumakanda Eldoret Kenya, and has been in this business for about four years.

Isaac was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer and he has no other history with any MFI.  He is applying for his third loan KES 30,000 with KADET LTD and he plans to purchase a new welding machine.

He hopes to operate a large scale welding machine to serve his customers better and in the future he wants to extend the same services by appyling for tenders in different companies.

loans.use: To purchase a new welding machine.

loans.name: Duncan

texts.en:
Duncan S., a 27-year-old man, is married to Polline Mwacharo. Polline is a businesslady, and they have three children together. Two of their children are twins (they are two years old), and their third child is a three-year-old girl.

To earn a living, Duncan sells curios in the Nairobi Maasai market, where there are many local customers and tourists that buy from him. Duncan has been running this business for the last 12 years, and his monthly income is typically 31,000 KES. Duncan describes himself as a very hardworking man.

Duncan was introduced to KADET by another KADET client, and ever since he has been satisfied with KADET's services. He is now seeking a loan in the amount of 40,000 KES ($500) to increase his stock of curios and to purchase other unique goods in order to attract additional customers. If the loan proceeds enable him to expand his business, he would like to open another shop. In the future, he plans on exporting his curios for additional income.

loans.use: To expand his business by increasing and diversifying his inventory

loans.name: Rashida's Group

texts.en:
Rashida, pictured with her hand raised, is a 40-year-old woman. She is married to G. H., who works for a private organization and earns very little income. They have six children, all of whom are young. Unfortunately, her children did not receive an education due to financial constraints. Now, her eldest son is looking for a job so that he can financially assist their family. Rashida prays to God and hopes that her son will find a job very soon.

In order to support her family, she sells milk for a living. She has a small shop adjacent to her home from which she operates the business. She has contracts with different milk suppliers, who come from nearby areas to provide her with milk.

She is now applying for a loan from a Kiva partner, Asasah, for her milk-selling business. With the loan proceeds, she would like to buy milk in larger quantities, which would enable her to increase her sales and income. She has been operating the business for 3 years, and she is confident about its future growth potential. This is her first loan application through Asasah, and she is hopeful that it will be a profitable experience.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing milk in bulk

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida G. is a 45-year-old woman from the village of Cabaruan. Zenaida is married and has six school-age children. To earn a living, Zenaida owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. More specifically, her primary source of income is derived from selling personal products, such as products from Avon, Natasha, and Marikina Shoe Exchange (MSE), in her local community. Zenaida has been engaged in this business for over 2 years, and she earns approximately 3,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2010, Zenaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. In turn, she expects to be better able to engage in business activities and to improve her family's standard of living. Zenaida is requesting a loan in the amount of 7,000 PHP ($175), which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan would be her first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business on account of the loan to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches, covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen/women, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional inventory

loans.name: Latifaan's Group

texts.en:
Latifaan, pictured with her hand raised, is a 51-year-old housewife. She lives with her family in a 3-room brick house in the city of Faisalabad, which is well-known for its textile industry. Her house is located in the area known as Bhaiwala, where she has been living for over 20 years. She and her husband have five children: 2 sons and 3 daughters. Her daughters are currently receiving their education, while her sons left school to start their own butcher shops in the market. Now that their businesses are growing and doing well, they should be able to provide financial support for the family.

Latifaan's husband’s name is S. H., and he is a butcher by profession. More specifically, he sells chicken meat to his clients. He has been engaged in this business for over 10 years, and customers prefer to purchase meat from his shop due to its freshness and good weight. Latifaan is applying for a loan from a Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. He plans on using the loan proceeds to purchase chicken meat in a larger quantity so that he can satisfy the increase in customers' orders and thereby increase his sales. She is an established client of Asasah, and this would be her third loan from Asasah. With respect to those prior loans, she repaid the loans on time and never missed group meetings.

loans.use: To meet customer demand by purchasing chickens in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 36-year-old, single woman living with her mother and three siblings in Lebanon. She has almost ten years of experience working as a beautician. Specifically, she offers her beauty services, such as manicures and pedicures, to local customers.

Now, she is requesting a loan in the amount of $1,200 from a Kiva partner, Ameen s.a.l., to expand her inventory and to buy new tools. She has high hopes for the future of her business, and she is looking to continue the expansion of her business in the coming year.

Women continue to play an important role in Lebanese society, especially in the development of the family. Women are able to serve as strong role models for their family while also helping to supplement their household incomes. In almost all parts of Lebanon, demand for beauty and fashion products continues to be high.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional inventory and tools

loans.name: Munkhtsetseg

texts.en:
Munkhtsetseg is a 51-year-old widow living with her daughter and son-in-law in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her daughter and son-in-law are students in local universities.   She owns a small piece of land with the family house in the suburb of the city.  Her eldest son lives separately with his family. 

In 1994, Munkhtsetseg started running a meat wholesale business together with her younger brother. They used to travel to countryside farms to buy meat and sell it in the city meat market. But since her brother passed away she was unable to travel to the countryside, and started a meat retail business. 

Her future plan is to give a good education for her kids and be able to pay university fees until their graduation. From the previous loan she has taken from us she bought a big freezer to store her meat products. This time she is requesting a loan to buy a small family car which will be used to carry her meat products.

loans.use: To buy a car to carry meat products.
